originalTitle: Nigeria denies report it paid 'huge' ransom to free pupils in mass abduction
title: Happy News! Children Are Home Safe in Nigeria!
content:
Hello, wonderful friends across our amazing continent of Africa! I'm your friendly news reporter, here to share some very important and happy news from a special country called Nigeria. Nigeria is a big country in West Africa, full of exciting places and kind people, just like you!

Good News! Children Are Home!

Guess what? There's super happy news for many families in Nigeria! Some children who were away from their homes and schools are now back with their mums, dads, brothers, and sisters! Isn't that wonderful? Everyone is so happy they are safe and sound. Their families missed them so much, and now they can give them big, warm hugs. It's like a big party in their hearts! The children can go back to playing games, learning new things at school, and being with all their friends and loved ones. It's a happy day for everyone! **Did You Know?** Nigeria has more people living in it than any other country in Africa! It's like a really, really big family!

What Happened?

A little while ago, something that made many people sad happened. Some children were taken away from their school. When someone is taken away without permission, we call it an "abduction." It's a very worrying thing, and everyone wants children to be safe always. The grown-ups, like the government and the police, worked very, very hard to bring the children back. They wanted to make sure every single child could return home safely. It was a big job, and many people were praying for the children to come home soon.

Was Money Paid? Nigeria Says "No"!

Now, let's talk about something that grown-ups discuss, but I'll explain it simply. Sometimes, when bad people take someone away, they ask for money to let them go. This money is called a "ransom." It's like saying, "Give us a lot of money, and then we will let this person go free." Some news stories said that the government of Nigeria paid a lot of money – a "huge ransom" – to get the children back. But guess what? The Nigerian government, which is like the big team of grown-ups who help run the country, said, "No, that's not true! We did not pay any money." They said very clearly that they did not give any ransom to get the children free. This is called a "denial" or a "rebuttal" – it means saying, "What you heard or read is not correct. It's not true." **Did You Know?** A government is like the main helpers for a whole country! They make rules, build schools and hospitals, and try to keep everyone safe and happy.

How Did the Children Come Home Then?

This is the most important part of the story! Even though some people thought money was paid, and the government said very clearly that it wasn't, the best part is that all the children are now safe at home. This means that maybe other smart ways were used to bring them back. Perhaps the brave police and other helpers worked very cleverly to find them. Maybe they talked to the people who took the children and convinced them to let them go without any money. The most important, most wonderful thing is that the children are safe and sound, back where they belong, ready to learn and play. We are all so happy for them!

A Big Police Boss Left His Job

Now for a little bit more news. Around the same time that everyone was so happy about the children coming home, something else happened in Nigeria. The main boss of all the police officers in Nigeria decided to leave his job. He was called the "Inspector General of Police," or we can just say the "police chief." Think of him like the captain of a very big team, where all the police officers across Nigeria are his teammates. His job was to make sure all the police worked well to keep people safe. This police chief decided to leave his job a little earlier than he was supposed to. Sometimes grown-ups decide to change jobs or retire. It's like when your teacher might decide to teach in a different school, or when a football coach decides to try something new. This police chief helped to keep everyone safe, and now someone new will take his place to continue that very important work. **Did You Know?** Police officers are brave people who wear uniforms! They work hard to keep us safe, solve problems, and help people who are in trouble. They are like real-life superheroes for our communities!

Why This News is Important

This news is important for many reasons, my friends. First, it reminds us that all children, everywhere, deserve to be safe, loved, and at home with their families. Every child is precious. Second, it shows that even when big problems happen, like children being taken away, people work together very hard to make things better. And third, it shows us that sometimes, what we hear might not be exactly true, and it's good to listen to what the people in charge, like the government, say. The Nigerian government wants everyone to know they are doing their very best to protect all children and make sure they are safe in their homes and schools.

Always Be Kind and Safe!

So, my little stars of Africa, remember to always be kind to each other and to listen to your parents and teachers. And remember that there are many brave people working hard every day to keep you safe. We hope that all children everywhere can live without fear and always feel happy and secure. Keep shining brightly! That's all for today from your friendly news reporter. Stay curious and stay kind!
summary: The Nigerian government denied reports that it paid a large ransom to free children who were abducted, stating they did not pay any money for the children's safe return home, while also noting that the country's top police official resigned around the same time.
whyMatters: This news is important because it shows that children who were taken away are now safe at home, and the government says they didn't pay money, reminding us that grown-ups are working hard to keep all children safe in Africa.

content: Bodo/Glimt knock out last year's finalists Inter Milan in one of the biggest upsets in Champions League history and now the team from the Arctic Circle is dreaming of how far they can go after reaching last 16.

originalTitle: West Brom sack head coach Ramsay after nine games
title: West Brom sack head coach Ramsay after nine games
content: West Bromwich Albion sack head coach Eric Ramsay after only nine games in charge at The Hawthorns.
